title: Rayado, New Mexico
text:
Rayado or Reyado (older Ryado) was the first permanent settlement in <a href="Colfax%20County%2C%20New%20Mexico">Colfax County</a>, <a href="New%20Mexico">New Mexico</a>, United States and an important stop on the <a href="Santa%20Fe%20Trail">Santa Fe Trail</a>. The name "Rayado" derives from the Spanish term for "streaked", perhaps in reference to the lot lines marked out by <a href="Lucien%20Maxwell">Lucien Maxwell</a>.
Some of the land in the townsite was purchased by <a href="Waite%20Phillips">Waite Phillips</a> in the 1920s and Phillips later donated it to the <a href="Boy%20Scouts%20of%20America">Boy Scouts of America</a> and it became part of the Philmont Scout Ranch.
Today, Rayado is the home of the Kit Carson Museum including his reconstructed home, and "La Posta", a <a href="Santa%20Fe%20Trail">Santa Fe Trail</a> stage stop dating from the 1850s.
Background.
Rayado is located where the mountain branch of the Santa Fe Trail intersects with the Cimarron Trail to <a href="Fort%20Leavenworth">Fort Leavenworth</a>.
Rayado is at , along <a href="New%20Mexico%20State%20Road%2021">State Route 21</a> at the extreme southeast corner of <a href="Philmont%20Scout%20Ranch">Philmont Scout Ranch</a>. One mile to the south is a classic <a href="Southwestern%20United%20States">southwestern</a> <a href="butte">butte</a>, called <a href="Kit%20Carson%20Mesa">Kit Carson Mesa</a>.
Rayado Mesa is located southeast of Rayado and Rayado Peak at is located west of Rayado on the <a href="Philmont%20Scout%20Ranch">Philmont Scout Ranch</a>.
Rayado was founded by Lucien Maxwell in 1848 at the end of the <a href="Mexican%E2%80%93American%20War">Mexican–American War</a>, as the first <a href="plain">plain</a>s settlement in New Mexico east of the mountain valleys of the <a href="Sangre%20de%20Cristo%20Mountains">Sangre de Cristo Mountains</a>. Because the plains were still subject to raids by <a href="Apache">Apache</a>, <a href="Comanche">Comanche</a> and other Indians, he had difficulty attracting settlers, so he convinced <a href="Kit%20Carson">Kit Carson</a> to move down from <a href="Taos%2C%20New%20Mexico">Taos</a> in 1849 to lend an air of safety to the enterprise.
Maxwell married his bride Luis Beaubien (daughter of <a href="Carlos%20Beaubien">Carlos Beaubien</a>) in Rayado and they lived there before moving to <a href="Cimarron%2C%20New%20Mexico">Cimarron</a>. A federal garrison post was established in Rayado in 1850 and lasted until <a href="Fort%20Union%20National%20Monument">Fort Union</a> was opened.
<a href="Jesus%20Gil%20Abreu">Jesus Gil Abreu</a> who also married a Beaubien daughter had his Abreu Ranch house there on the banks of the Rayado Creek from 1859 until his death in 1911. There was a post office there from 1873 to 1919.
